He always plays in perfect time.

meanings.def: used to say that something should have happened before now
if you do something against time, you do it as fast as you can because you do not have much time

meanings.def: at one time; together

meanings.def: sometimes

meanings.def: happening before you were born or can remember or before you lived, worked, etc. somewhere

meanings.def: before the usual time in somebody’s life when something happens

meanings.def: old-fashioned in your ideas, methods, etc.
to be able to take advantage of opportunities when they come

meanings.def: to still be alive after the time when you were expected to die

meanings.def: used to encourage somebody who has not been successful at something

meanings.def: to wait for the right time to do something

meanings.def: to do something in order to delay an event, a decision, etc.

meanings.def: to say or decide that it is time for something to finish

meanings.def: to have no difficulties or problems

meanings.def: to enjoy yourself very much
to like and be interested in somebody/something

to have nothing to do or not be busy

meanings.def: to make marching movements without moving forwards

Let’s take a break.
The drug brought a brief respite from the pain.
Take time out to relax by the pool.
This delay gives the party a breathing space in which to sort out its policies.

idioms.idiom: there’s a first time for everything
idioms.def: the fact that something has not happened before does not mean that it will never happen
used when you have failed to do something twice and hope that you will succeed the third time

idioms.idiom: time after time | time and (time) again
idioms.def: often; on many or all occasions
examples: You will get a perfect result time after time if you follow these instructions.
Time and again, the girls have shown how strong and determined they can be.

idioms.def: one and a half times the usual rate of pay
examples: We get time and a half on Sundays.

idioms.def: time seems to pass very quickly
examples: How time flies! I've got to go now.
Time has flown since the holiday began.

idioms.def: time is valuable, and should not be wasted
used to say that somebody can wait for something to happen or can wait before doing something
used to say that something used to happen in the past
examples: Time was when you could go for a walk in the country and not see another person for miles.
Time was when we never needed to lock our house at night.

idioms.idiom: time (alone) will tell | only time will tell
idioms.def: used to say that you will have to wait for some time to find out the result of a situation
examples: Only time will tell if the treatment has been successful.

idioms.idiom: the whole time | all the time
idioms.def: during the whole of a particular period of time
examples: My keys were in my pocket the whole time (= while I was looking for them).
He drums his fingers on the table the whole time—it's very annoying.

meanings.def: to measure how long it takes for something to happen or for somebody to do something
examples: time something ‘How long does it take to get to Leeds from here?’ ‘I don’t know, I’ve never timed it.’
time something at something The winner was timed at 20.4 seconds.
time how long… Time how long it takes you to run ten laps.
Time how long it takes you to answer the questions.

meanings.def: to arrange to do something or arrange for something to happen at a particular time
examples: time something for something She timed her arrival for shortly after 3.
be… timed Their visit was perfectly timed.
The runners set off at precisely timed intervals.
Their request was poorly timed (= it was made at the wrong time).
time something + adv. If we time it right, we should miss the traffic.
‘I hope we're not too early.’ ‘You couldn't have timed it better!’
be timed to do something The announcement of her new role was timed to coincide with the launch of her latest book.
The meeting is timed for 2 o'clock.
The schedule must be carefully timed.
This campaign is well timed.
a beautifully timed entrance
The show is timed to coincide with the launch of her new book.

meanings.def: to hit or kick a ball at a particular moment in a sports game
examples: She timed the pass perfectly.
a beautifully timed shot

meanings.def: a popular US news magazine, published every week. It was started in 1923 by Henry Luce (1898-1967), the husband of Clare Booth Luce, and Briton Hadden (1898-1929). It created offices for its journalists around the world and has developed a particular style of writing which is sometimes called Timese. The magazine now has several different international versions. People consider it a great honour to have their picture on the cover of the magazine, and as a special feature every year it chooses a man or woman of the year.
